newsitem.title: UK: FTSE 100 set for short sharp shock - UK analyst.
newsitem.headline: FTSE 100 set for short sharp shock - UK analyst.

text.p: The UK's FTSE 100 index could be poised for a sharp setback of perhaps 240 points, though the longer-term bull trend remains intact, chart analyst Robin Griffiths at brokerage HSBC James Capel said on Wednesday.
Griffiths said he expects the index to see a sharp downward move before resuming a recent advance which he sees peaking during the early part of 1997.
"I'm expecting a short sharp shock," Griffiths said, "a tactical setback which we will use to tell institutions they have their last chance to buy before a 500 point run up to the top."
"This setback began this morning," he said. "The maximum swing is 240-points from the top."

Griffiths said the FTSE 100 had reached 4,080 and was now going for a retracement of part of its rise. He said the index could come all the way back to 3,830 without upsetting the long term bull trend.
At 1516 GMT the FTSE 100 was down 27.6 points at 4,029.6, extending its decline since hitting a record close of 4,073.1 on October 21.
